awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of an Isotope Ratio Mass Spectrometer for using stable isotopes to study complex ecological systems
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Michigan Technological University to obtain an isotope ratio mass spectrometer for the analysis of stable isotopes of carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, sulfur and hydrogen in environmental samples. Faculty and staff will use the instrument to trace these elements in studies of aquatic and terrestrial ecosystem processes. It is important for science students to have hands-on experience with essential analytical tools, and through this purchase, students in a wide variety of fields at Michigan Tech will be able to incorporate the use of isotopes into their own research. The team at Michigan Tech will fully integrate isotopic research into classroom education in upper-level ecosystem science courses to prepare future scientists who are fully capable of using advanced techniques to investigate environmental issues and their potential solutions. The state-of-the-science instrument also will aid in attracting the best possible graduate students and candidates for faculty positions in ecology and environmental science, both of which are areas of study known to attract diverse populations into STEM careers.

The new instrument will triple the types of elemental isotopic analyses that can be provided to Michigan Tech students and researchers and their colleagues, fostering collaborations among ecosystem scientists, biologists, hydrologists, chemists and geologists. Researchers will use isotopic analyses for diverse purposes including: assessing origins of migratory species such as birds, bats and butterflies; separating recent versus older sources of greenhouse gas fluxes from wetlands to identify possible feedbacks to the climate system; understanding the contributions of stormflow and groundwater to streamflow to help predict the potential for future flooding as storm intensities increase; separating contributions of aquatic and terrestrial vegetation to the diets of wild species; and assessing impacts of recent and past droughts on forest productivity through analysis of tree rings and foliage and determining the soil depths from which different plant species can access water. Results from these studies and other research performed with the instrument will be widely disseminated in peer-reviewed publications and at scientific meetings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In 2021, researchers from Michigan Technological University used National Science Foundation funds to purchase a new Delta V Plus Isotope Ratio Mass Spectrometer (IRMS) and peripherals for the analysis of stable isotopes of C, N, O, S, and H in solids, gases and water. This instrument, which replaced a twenty-year-old, obsolete IRMS, became operational in 2022 and is helping scientists at Michigan Tech trace common elements through aquatic and terrestrial ecosystems, aiding studies of a wide variety of ecological processes. Compared to previous instruments at Michigan Tech, the new IRMS enables analysis of isotopes of additional elements and in a wider variety of sample types, greatly expanding the types of questions that researchers and students can address. The new instrument has the ability to analyze 13C, 15N, 2H, 34S, and 18O in solids; 2H and 18O of water; and 13CO2, 13CH4, 15N2O and N218O in air.  Only three of these analyses were available previously at Michigan Tech. Thus, the IRMS is supporting new, exciting lines of investigation, such as: 1) using 13C and 18O in foliage and tree rings to study plant water use efficiency and impacts of climatic variation on current and past tree growth; 2) using 2H and 13C to understand habitat use and assess origins and migratory patterns of bird, bat and butterfly populations; 3) using 18O and 2H to identify seasonal patterns in depth of plant water uptake to help predict how different species might fare in a changing climate; 4) using 18O and 2H to assess groundwater and stormflow contributions to streamflow in northern states, areas of groundwater intrusion into streams required by certain fish species, and glacial melt inputs to streams and wetlands in the Andes; 5) understanding the contributions of aquatic and terrestrial vegetation to the diets of moose and aquatic organisms; 6) separating recent versus older sources of greenhouse gas emissions from wetlands experiencing altered water table depth due to climate change, to understand the degree to which long-stored carbon may be released to the atmosphere; and 7) using 15N and 13C to study carbon and nitrogen cycles in terrestrial ecosystems.

At Michigan Tech, it is important that students gain experience with essential analytical tools. The new IRMS helps achieve this goal by letting instructors more fully integrate research and education. Courses at both the graduate and undergraduate level now can demonstrate the use of stable isotopic methods for investigating a wide variety of ecological questions.  Students in courses such as Forest and Landscape Hydrology, Wetlands, Snow Hydrology, Tree Physiology, Measuring Plants and their Environment, Forest Ecophysiology, and Advanced Terrestrial Ecology will utilize data from the IRMS, often from samples they have collected, to investigate ecological principles and study environmental science issues. In addition, students in the graduate Stable Isotopes in Ecology course will gain practical experience in using stable isotopes to answer ecological questions, enhancing the toolkit of skills they graduate with, and ultimately leading to additional investigations of ecological questions as their careers advance.
